items.title: If you had the chance to be immortal, would you take it? - Sarah Stroud and Michael Vazquez
items.author: TED-Ed
items.content:
<article>Explore different philosophers‚Äô ideas on immortality and dig into their theories about the positives and negatives of eternal life.

--

While cleaning out your uncle‚Äôs attic you find a chest with a sparkling potion. The attached tag declares drinking this liquid will make you immortal. Your body will be frozen at its current age, and these effects would be final and irreversible. The instructions are clear ‚Äî the only question is, do you drink the potion? Sarah Stroud and Michael Vazquez explore this philosophical debate.

Lesson by Sarah Stroud and Michael Vazquez, directed by Skirmanta Jakaitƒó.

This video was produced in collaboration with the Parr Center for Ethics, housed within the renowned Philosophy Department at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. The Parr Center is committed to integrating abstract work in ethical theory with the informed discussion of practical ethical issues, and prides itself on the development of innovative and inclusive approaches to moral and civic education.

items.content:
<article>The Vera C. Rubin telescope has just released its first images, and they‚Äôre spectacular.  
If you love learning about science as much as I do, head to http://brilliant.org/astrum to start for free. You'll also receive 20% off a premium annual subscription, giving you unlimited access to everything on Brilliant.

On a mountain in Chile, the Vera C. Rubin Observatory, with its massive 3.2-billion-pixel camera, is capturing images that rival those from the James Webb Space Telescope. items.title: How did coalition forces take down ISIS?
items.author: Imperial War Museums
items.content:
<article>ISIS once held vast territory in Iraq and Syria, spreading terror across the globe. Now, its caliphate lies in ruins. But how did it rise so fast, and what led to its collapse? Using the Imperial War Museum‚Äôs collection, IWM curator Jack Gelsthorpe explores the dramatic rise and fall of one of the world‚Äôs most feared terrorist groups.

Chapters:
00:00 ‚Äì The Rise and Fall of ISIS Intro 
00:50 - Iraq pre 2011
01:33 - The Iraqi Government 2010-2013 and disenfranchisement of Sunnis and Kurds
03:35 - How can we explain the rise and emergence of ISIS?
06:03 - Weaknesses in ISF and peshmerga
07:12 - Fall of Mosul
09:56 - Life under ISIS
11:08 - Camp Speicher
12:09 - Yazidi genocide
13:32 - Operation Inherent Resolve and Operation Shader
17:32 - Terror attacks
18:42 - Liberation of Mosul
21:04 - Has ISIS really been defeated?

items.title: What are truffles, and why are they so expensive? - Carolyn Beans
items.author: TED-Ed
items.content:
<article>Dig into the truffle‚Äôs unique and mysterious biology to find out what makes them so rare and the limitations of farming them.

--

Truffles are one of the world‚Äôs most expensive foods‚Äî in part because global demand often outstrips supply. And truffles are becoming even more rare and more expensive as deforestation and climate change shrink their suitable terrain. But why are these fungi so rare? And why don‚Äôt we just farm more of them? Carolyn Beans digs into the truffle‚Äôs unique and somewhat mysterious biology.

Lesson by Carolyn Beans, directed by Denys Spolitak.

items.content:

items.title: Nazi Collapse Captured in Brutal Uncensored Footage
items.author: History Hit
items.content:
<article>Watch our new documentary on the final days of World War II, as Hitler refused to admit defeat, and his German soldiers suffered the Soviet attack on the Eastern Front. 

Told through never-before-seen accounts and rare archive footage, the film reveals how the Nazi regime clung to power, sacrificing countless lives in a futile bid to delay the inevitable collapse.

It is January 1945 in Germany. The war is lost, but the killing continues. The once mighty Wehrmacht has been driven back on all fronts. In the west, Allied troops are poised to surge into the German heartland.

To the east, the Red Army continues its bloody march towards Berlin. The German war machine is on the brink of total collapse.

In the capital, as Goebbels prepares the German people for a final, desperate last stand, Hitler descends deeper into a world of fantasy. In five months, both will be dead, along with countless others, and Berlin will be reduced to rubble.

The Nazi regime is no more. This is the story of that downfall.

See and hear letters and diaries of the men and women who were present; it's through their words that we will experience the final bloody act of Hitler‚Äôs Third Reich, while he hid away in the F√ºhrerbunker.

items.title: New Meme Stocks Just Dropped!
items.author: Patrick Boyle
items.content:
<article>üëâ To learn for free on Brilliant, go to https://brilliant.org/patrick/. Brilliant‚Äôs also given our viewers 20% off an annual Premium subscription, which gives you unlimited daily access to everything on Brilliant.

This summer, a bizarre new trend hit Wall Street: Chinese meme stocks. Promoted in WhatsApp groups, Reddit threads, and even under fake YouTube comments, these obscure Chinese companies soared ‚Äî and then collapsed ‚Äî wiping out billions in investor savings. In this video, we explore how Regencell Biosciences briefly reached a $38 billion valuation selling what looks suspiciously like curry ingredients as medicine, we try to understand why the FBI is calling it ‚Äúramp and dump‚Äù fraud, and how scammers are impersonating brokers, analysts, and even YouTubers to lure in victims.

We‚Äôll compare these knockoff meme stocks to America‚Äôs domestically produced meme stock madness ‚Äî GameStop, AMC, and the DORK stocks ‚Äî and ask: is this just low-quality IP theft, or a new frontier in financial absurdity?

items.title: How we got hooked on credit cards - Nidhi Upadhyaya
items.author: TED-Ed
items.content:
<article>Dig into the history of credit cards in the United States, and how they have evolved since the 1950s into the industry we know today.

--

Today, credit cards are a $500 billion-a-year industry. Banks consider these lines of credit when deciding whether or not to approve loans, incentivizing customers to maintain multiple credit cards. So, how did this lending system originate? And how did they get to be so popular? Nidhi Upadhyaya digs into the history of credit cards in the United States.

Lesson by Nidhi Upadhyaya, directed by Jeff Le Bars, JetPropulsion.space.

items.title: The Gladius (RA Summer Lecture)
items.author: Royal Armouries
items.content:
<article>Speaker: Dr Jaime Kaminski, Sussex Archaeological Society 

Learn about the fearsome Roman short sword ‚Äì the Gladius. This weapon is synonymous with the expansion of Rome. Dr Kaminski will explore the history and typology of the iconic legionary weapon. A rare surviving sword in the Royal Armouries collection will be examined (X.5583)

Subscribe to our channel for more videos about arms and armour

items.title: Hands-on with Hidden Pen Guns with firearms expert Jonathan Ferguson
items.author: Royal Armouries
items.content:
<article>In this episode of What Is This Weapon?, Jonathan takes a close look at examples of concealed pen guns from the Royal Armouries collection.

Watch as Jonathan breaks down their engineering and reveals why these unusual objects endure as icons of concealment.
